Description:
In business ethics, we consider business actions and decisions in the light of moral principles
and values, and ask whether ethical motives in business activity woUniversity of Limpopod make business better
and more successfUniversity of Limpopo; ethical values already implied in business and market activity, assess
how business does and shoUniversity of Limpopod affect our individual and social lives, and ask what role
business and its values (coUniversity of Limpopod) play in our society as a whole; examine issues and conflicts
that typically arise in business that have moral aspects to them, such as the way employers
ModUniversity of Limpopoe Content:
treat their employees, employees their employers, and the ways businesses treat their
competitors, their customers, their society, and even their environment; the practical
question of whether a (morally) good life can be lived by those who wholehearted devote
themselves to business success. These matters all centre on questions about human action
and the good life.
Students taking this course will learn to
• identify the moral questions that business activity specifically creates
• distinguish between ethical and other types of values
• recognize ethical considerations and values relevant to business activity
• evaluate common beliefs about ethics—especially common beliefs about the role
of ethics in business
• reflect on the nature of business, realize alternatives models for conducting
business
Name: Business Ethics and Values IIA

Description: The relationship between politics and administration has shown to be a complex one. This has generated a considerable debate on whether the governments should combine or separate such activities. Public administration and related disciplines; the domain of the discipline of Public Administration; the politics-administration, dichotomy the politicized bureaucracy models; the British permanent model and the American Hybrid model; the complex Public Administration environment and politics, Institutional arrangements and politico administration.

Description: HCEL012 seeks to introduce a way of analyzing the syntax (or grammar) of English using a discoursal approach. This means that sentences will not be analyzed in isolation (as is often done in traditional formal linguistics). Instead the focus will be on the functions that sentences and larger units of text perform (locutionary, illocutionary and perlocutionary functions) and their formal structure will be analyzed in terms of their functions. In other words the relation between form and function will be studied.
Name: English Sentence Analysis

Description: political economy. These issues include Africa’s unequal incorporation into the world, economy and the continent’s transformation into a supplier of raw materials and labour, and producer of cash crops for the metropolis. This has resUniversity of Limpopoted in the skewing of the, local economy, land dispossession, the breakdown of society and the imposition of a, new political order under colonialism. Students will examine the process of the transfer, of political power to nationalist or anti-colonial movements. However, they will realise, through the study of underdevelopment, Structural Adjustment Programmes and, globalisation that, despite Africa’s efforts to be become economically independent, through programmes of African Socialism and a New Economic Order, Africa is as, economically managed, but ironically, since the end of the Cold War, more marginalised, than ever before. The modUniversity of Limpopoe will conclude with an examination of whether Africa is in, the throes of a ‘new’ 21st century scramble for its scarce resources., ,
Name: Political Economy Of Africa

Description: The activity of public administration is complex and requires practitioners who in their line of operations understand the political dynamics, the society and the economic models used by their government. This module therefore aims to equip students with the necessary knowledge required for understanding the political dynamics, the society and the economic models used by government. The module will cover the following themes – Politics and government. Political culture, economy and political parties; The role of pressure groups, proletariat and propaganda in politics;; The rival theories of the state; The role of the state; The state in a global era; Economic systems (capitalisms and socialism of the world); Social structure and divisions, identity politics and multiculturalism; Legitimacy and political stability.

Description:
Clinical medicine is concerned with the diagnosis and
management of the person with an illness. The modUniversity of Limpopoe
includes the doctor-patient relationship; examination
methods used by a doctor to elicit the necessary
information from the person with an illness or a person
accompanying the ill person in order to help him/her, as well
as the demands and responsibilities of the profession.
By the end of this rotation a student will be able to demonstrate
the following:
Create an optimal doctor/patient relationship, paying attention to
the patient’s background and cUniversity of Limpopoture, as well as to the patient’s
experience of the health care system.
Conduct an appropriate interview, including obtaining the
medical history and the documentation thereof.
Perform a systematic physical examination and document such
information.
Evaluate the importance of the mutual interaction of disease,
circumstances of life and the psyche of the patient.
Discuss the demands that the consUniversity of Limpopotation places on you/the
physician, including the health risks for the doctor.
Describe the principles of clinical epidemiology.

Description:
The course is designed to provide a general
understanding of physics concepts and principles. The
emphasis of this course is on understanding concepts
and applying them in medicine and clinical situations.
Physical concepts dealt with are: Measurement; Work,
energy and Power, Statics, Elastic properties of
materials; Heat (thermodynamics); Dynamics;
Liquids/Fluids; Static Electricity; Direct currents;
Electromagnetism; Induced currents; Waves and sound;
light; mirrors, lenses and imaging systems; Introduction
to nuclear physics; Ionising radiation; Radiation from the
environment and the sun.

The student will:
&bUniversity of Limpopol; have a solid conceptual understanding of the way
the real world works based on a few fundamental
principles of physics
&bUniversity of Limpopol; be able to solve realistic problems using logical
reasoning and quantitative problem solving skills
&bUniversity of Limpopol; apply physics concepts and problem solving skills to
new situations;
&bUniversity of Limpopol; effectively communicate technical information
Name: Physics for Medicine

Description:
The modUniversity of Limpopoe investigates the relevant disease processes,
clinical pictures and their management with respect to the
respiratory system. It looks at the normal structure of the
respiratory system, its relationship to function and how these
are altered in the various disease states.
At the end of the modUniversity of Limpopoe, the student shoUniversity of Limpopod have developed
the following capabilities with regards to the respiratory system:
Describe, identify and illustrate the macroscopic and
microscopic and embryology of anatomical structures of the
respiratory system
Discuss the physiological processes and nuances that are
involved in the respiratory system
Provide sound reasoning and judgement on the disease state
by integrating information on the anatomy, physiology and
biochemistry of the respiratory system.
Recognise symptoms of respiratory orientations and relate
these to disease conditions, interpret diagnostic procedures,
and perform an examination of the respiratory system.
Discuss the presenting signs and symptoms, pathophysiology,
diagnosis (including diagnostic testing), and patient
management (including, but not limited to, pharmacotherapeutics,
therapeutic procedures, patient education and
preventive measures)
Name: Respiratory System

 Discuss the origin and scope of the science of anatomy and describe several of its branches, viz: microscopic (cytology, histology), gross (surface, regional, and systemic) and developmental (embryology).  Name and describe different levels at which the human body is organized, viz: molecUniversity of Limpopoar, cellUniversity of Limpopoar, tissue, organ and system.  Name the organ systems present in the human body and describe their main components and functions.  Describe the anatomical position and its significance with regard to anatomical terminology.  Understand and describe anatomical terms relating to regions, directions, planes etc.  Draw and label a time-line indicating the 3 major stages of development.  Describe the location and timing of fertilization and the female reproductive cycle.  List the 3 major periods of pregnancy and teratogenesis  State the timing and resUniversity of Limpopot of cleavage.  Sketch and label the features of a blastocyst, and indicate the developmental fate of each part.  Describe the timing, location, and mechanism of implantation.  Understand and describe embryogenesis, the fate of the 3 primary germ layers and development of neural tube and brain.  Describe the development, structure and function of the placenta  (placentation).  State some of the significant changes in maternal anatomy during pregnancy, and their physiological consequences.  Identify and describe the divisions of the skeleton and explain the functions.  Explain how bones are classified and be able to identify and describe long, short, flat, irregUniversity of Limpopoar, and sesamoid bones.  Define a joint and describe the four structural categories of joints.  Sketch and label the features of a simple synovial joint.

At the end of the modUniversity of Limpopoe the student will be able to: - Demonstrate practical skills in assessing patient suitability for contact lens wear; - Demonstrate basic clinical decision-making skills in interpreting assessment findings; - Perform and evaluate a pre-fitting assessment of a contact lens wearer - Explain the three general contact lens fitting procedures; - Compare Keratometry contact lens fitting measurements; - Explain the three point touch fitting of Hydrogel contact lens; - Identify vision threatening common pathogens with contact lens wear; - Explain application guidelines of cosmetics with contact lens wear; - Explain contact lens complications seen on the cornea; - Explain the areas of the palpebral conjunctiva for recording purposes ; - Identify non-vision complications with contact lens wear;

Description:
The course provides an introduction to the primary care clinic. Clinical diagnostic and critical thinking skills are required, emphasizing patient examination, assessment and dispensing plan. Continued emphasis will be placed on emergency care procedures, infection control procedures, diagnostic coding, ethics and communication with patient, review of library resources, review of laboratory equipment’s, care and maintenance. The student will be required to participate in a fUniversity of Limpopol series of clinical rotations within the University Optometric Clinic and external clinical site training such as Mankweng Hospital as well as approved Optometric practices with Optical Laboratories around the locality of Polokwane.

Clinical Practice 1 is designed to facilitate the student’s transition into clinical internship. The course is hands-on clinical experience that builds upon the first two years of Optometry knowledge and skills. Included will be casepresentations, seminar-based discussion and clinical teaching of diagnosis and clinical management. The student will provided with the widest range of clinical patient care opportunities possible to assist the students to integrate knowledge and skills in first and second year with the clinical subject s and practice
Name: Clinical Practice 1

Description:
Developmental milestones of gross and fine motor function, cognition, speech and communication and vision development. Vision and school performance; delayed development and vision therapy.

At the end of the modUniversity of Limpopoe the student will be able to: - Explain the development of basic visual anatomy and visual function; - Explain normal development of the child; - Explain theories of normal child visual spatial development; - Discuss anomalous development and pathologies present in children; - Perform and adapt diagnostic ophthalmic procedures specific to examining children from birth to five years; - Develop and adapt a management plan that is specific to visual anomalies in children; - Manage visual problems of children from birth to five years; - Provide and educate the care-giver on home based vision therapy; - Educate care-giver on the importance of infection control and follow –up of treatment; - Identify, assess and clinically manage visual problems presenting in children with Learning disabilities, mental retardation and child abuse; - Write reports and refer to relevant professionals involved in child care.
Name: Paediatric Optometry

Description:
Introduction to the Science of Anatomy and its subdivisions; levels of
organization and anatomical terminology; introduction to human embryonic
and foetal development. Skeletal system: the skull, with particular reference
to the orbit. External structure of the globe. Muscular system: muscle types,
the extra-ocular muscle and the common tendinous ring. Cardiovascular
system: heart and major vessels; blood supply and drainage of the head,
neck, brain, orbit and globe. Neurulation and the structure of the adult brain;
cranial nerves associated with the eye and orbit; autonomic nervous system.

Learning Outcomes

Introduction to anatomy
- The learner should be able to
-Explain the origin and scope of the science of anatomy, its branches and
different levels at which the human body is organized; understand the organ
systems and their functions, anatomical position and anatomical terms and
their uses.
Introduction to embryology
The learner should be able to
-Understand and explain the process of ovulation to implantation,
mechanism of embryogenesis, and the fate of the 3 primary germ layers,
placentation, and the processes of neural tube formation, neurulation and
somites, the development of the eye.
Skeletal, muscular systems and Joints
- The learner should be able to
- Identify the skull and name the various bones of the face and skull with
particular attention to the orbit cavity; understand and describe the facial
skeleton and its link with the bones of the skull, the types/classification of
joints and their movements and functions,

- understand the three muscle types in the body with reference to extra-
and intra ocular muscles, their function and the common tendinous ring,

muscles of the head and neck.
Cardiovascular system
-Understand, identify and able to explain the components of the circulatory,
systems and their respective functions; the thoracic cavity, the gross
anatomy of the heart, great vessels and lungs, the blood supply and drainage
of the head, neck, brain, orbit and globe.
External Structure of the globe
The learner should be able:
- To describe the external features of the globe, detailed structure of the
globe and associated structures, the three ocular layers and their functions,
The Nervous system
- Structure of adult brain, divisions of the nervous system, cranial nerves
associated with the eye and orbit; autonomic nervous system.
Name: Gross Anatomy :Head & Neck

Description:
Students spend eight fUniversity of Limpopol weeks executing the planned nutrition programmes at primary health care facilities, schools, and other community based centres (e.g. community – based projects – such as greenery, income generation; support groups) or be involved in district plans.  Maternal Services- Prenatal and postnatal care- weight gain/loss, micronutrient supplementation, nutrition counselling and education  Child Health Services – breastfeeding; complementary feeding, growth monitoring and promotion; vitamin A supplementation Integrated Management of Childhood Illnesses- nutritional aspects of diarrhoeal diseases, acute respiratory infection, measles and any nutrition related activities.  Nutritional counselling and education to the public  National School Nutrition Programmes  Early Childhood Development

At the end of the modUniversity of Limpopoe the student shoUniversity of Limpopod be able to:  Implement, monitor and evaluate community nutrition programmes  Organize and mobilize resources, for example develop lesson plans, counseling cards, recipes, teaching aids to be used during the implementation of the planned programme  Conduct a very simple evaluation and/or improvement of existing community nutrition programmes  Render nutrition services to the community through health centers, early childhood development centers, schools and community based project.  Compile and disseminate an implementation report to the relevant stakeholders.  Present and communicate to the different groups within a community and disseminate scientific/evidence based nutrition information

Description:
The content of this modUniversity of Limpopoe will include knowledge and understanding of: spectacle lens designs, power, and thickness; various methods of determining the power of a spectacle lens and prism; compounding and resolving of prisms. Knowledge and understanding of lens characteristics and coatings; prisms; high powered lenses and aberrations. Lens identification, power determination and lens thickness measurements will be performed in practical. MUniversity of Limpopotifocal lenses (bifocal; trifocal; progressive addition lenses) Practical: 3 Hour practical per week Each student is expected to obtain the power of lenses using hand neutralization and vertometry, and determine prism power using a tangent scale.

At the end of the modUniversity of Limpopoe the student shoUniversity of Limpopod be able to: - Differentiate the types of ophthalmic lens materials used for vision corrective devices ( e. spectacle, contact lenses etc); - Explain basic considerations of lens design principles; - Demonstrate how to record sphero-cylindrical (astigmatic) lenses; - Perform transposition of cylindrical and spherocylindrical lenses (from plus to minus or minus to plus cylinder form); - Perform hand neutralization of spherical and spherocylindrical lenses; - Verify the power of any spectacle lens using the focimeter; - Differentiate the types of toric lenses; - Perform toric transposition; - Show how to use the lens measure; - Perform relevant calcUniversity of Limpopoation of lens curvatures and thickness using lens measures; - Discuss the principle of prism; - Show how to induce prismatic effect in a spectacle lens (decentration); - Resolve compound prism; - Draw and explain the different type of mUniversity of Limpopotifocal lenses; - Explain the reason behind dispensing tinted (photochromic) protective lenses and lens coating (e.g. AR); - Discuss broad-based clinical applications of lenses; - Explain and differentiate high power lenses e.g. lenticUniversity of Limpopoar lenses, high index lenses etc.

Description:
The modUniversity of Limpopoe investigates the normal functions (physiology),
structure (anatomy and histology) as well as disease
conditions and abnormalities of the reticUniversity of Limpopoo-endothelial and
haematological systems, as well as the relationship between
structure and function, so as to have a basic understanding
of the pathophysiology, clinical picture and management of
illnesses associated with this system. This modUniversity of Limpopoe also aims
to enable a newly-qualified doctor to identify diseases of the
reticUniversity of Limpopoo-edothelial haematological system (as well as
paediatric malignancies) that are important in the South
African popUniversity of Limpopoation and, on the grounds of this knowledge of
normal and abnormal, be able to treat the problem
appropriately and, where possible, take preventative action.
Students will be able to:
Relate the structure and function of the system to the normal
state of a patient.
Integrate knowledge of the normal state with that of the disease
state.
Interrogate case studies of the disease state in order to identify
the disease and propose management thereof.
Name: ReticUniversity of Limpopoo-endothelial System and Haematology

Description:
This modUniversity of Limpopoe will cover the basic introduction to causes
(aetiology) of organic disease and pathophysiologic processes:
Cell injury, adaptation and damage; Cell death; Acute and
chronic inflammation; recovery, regeneration; Wound healing,
fibrosis; Haemodynamic variations; Shock; Thrombosis; Basic
concepts of the immune response; Disorders of the immune
system; Carcinogenesis; Genetic and paediatric illnesses;
Structure and characteristics of microbes; Normal body flora;
Principles of infection: bacteriology, parasitology and virology;
Host–parasite relationships and microbial pathogenesis; The
microbiology laboratory and principles of diagnosis;
Antimicrobial chemotherapy
The student will be able to:
Broadly discuss different causes (aetiology) of diseases,
including microorganisms and viruses (infective aetiological
factors of diseases), trauma etc. using correct medical
terminology.
Relate the different possible events (pathogenesis) which can
occur following exposure to aetiological factors and which lead
to damage and/or death of cells and tissue in humans to
disease states.
Describe the changes in normal morphology and function that
can resUniversity of Limpopot from cell damage or cell death, and how this can
cause clinical symptoms and signs.
The principles of antimicrobial therapy and hospital hygiene will
be mastered.
Name: Essentials of Disease Processes

At the end of the modUniversity of Limpopoe the student will be able to:  Familiarize themselves with assessment tools and use them appropriately;  Conduct Interview to elicit the socioeconomic background and medical information;  Conduct Anthropometric measurements, Skinfolds, Body Measurements Identify and relate the indices with reference standards;  Analyse and Interpret resUniversity of Limpopots appropriately;  Record resUniversity of Limpopots clearly and accurately;  Identify limitations of various measurements and indices;  Conduct an accurate systematic clinical assessment and interpret resUniversity of Limpopots;  Demonstrate an understanding of advantages and limitations of biochemical assessment;  Identify different specimen used and when are they applicable to test for nutrients;  Relate the resUniversity of Limpopots of biochemical tests to disease conditions;  Confidently conduct and educate patients around finger pricking and urine testing skills;  Describe different tools used to collect dietary information;  Familiarise themselves with different dietary intake tools;  Understand the benefits and limitations of each of those tools;  Analyse and interpret dietary intake data;  Integrate all other information to draw a clinical judgement/diagnosis;  Differential between screening and assessment;

Name: HUMAN MICROANATOMY

Description:
The module is elementary/introductory in approach. Definitions of various
pathological/clinical/medical terms, basic human structure and function as well molecular
interactions at cellular level, classical normal and “diseased” or transformed
cells/tissues/organs/systems, the importance of laboratory observations in identifying
these abnormalities, factors causing abnormalities in typical/classical pathological
conditions (reference will be made to various fields of medical science), basic or
elementary basis of disease pathogenesis, Management and control of selected
pathological conditions and recent developments/advances and innovations in the
medical science fraternity.
At the end of the module, the students should be able to:
 Define various medical terms and competitively apply them in both oral and
written responses/discussions.
 Form a basic connection between anatomical organ systems and their
functions as they are mediated by biochemical systems in their cells.
 Distinguish normal and diseased/transformed systems as indicated by
particular laboratory observations. For examples, Diabetes is due to elevated
blood sugar levels from normal, STIs are a results by infection with pathogenic
micro-organisms, immunodeficiencies occur due to abnormalities of the bone
marrow and albinism or haemophilia are a result of nucleic acid
abnormalities/aberrations.
 Relate a particular pathological condition with its causative agent.
 Explain in simple terms, how the causative agent cause the pathological
condition.
 Explain the basis of disease management and control including; treatment,
immunization, organ transplantation, counseling, nutrition, body wellness
(exercise) , palliative care, etc.
 Keep informed about recent information on developments in biomedical
research, disease treatment and the ever expanding scopes of medical
sciences.
Name: MEDICAL SCIENCES INTRODUCTION II

Description:
(1) Basic ecology, in which the fundamental ecological concepts are illustrated with a balanced overview of the
applications of these concepts in populations, communities and ecosystems. Animal associations are discussed as
the relationships among members of populations and communities within an ecosystem.
(2) Freshwater ecology: freshwater ecosystems with the emphasis on interactions among animal and plant species,
structure, biotic and abiotic components and water quality standards. The role of fish in the ecosystem is studied
from the point of view of resource partitioning, physiological adaptations, fish health and the ecosystem and
pollution.
(3) Wildlife Management: introduction to ecological principles of wildlife conservation and the rationale for
conservation management. It deals with the practical applications of ecological principles in the design of
management plans for conservation purposes and commercial wildlife farming.

Description:
The content of this modUniversity of Limpopoe consists of a knowledge and application component. The knowledge
component will deal with laboratory procedures and process for wastewater, Oxygen Demand Tests,
Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD), including carbonaceous (CBOD) and soluble (dissolved) BOD
fractions, Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD), and Specific Oxygen Uptake Rate (SOUR), Solids Tests
“Settleometer tests, Total and Volatile Suspended Solids (TSS & TVSS), Mixed Liquor Suspended and
Volatile Solids (MLSS and MLVSS), Process control calcUniversity of Limpopoations “Food/Microorganism Ratio (F/M), Sludge
Age, Mean Cell Residence Time (MCRT), Sludge inventory control – waste activated sludge rates,
Chlorination and de-chlorination, Chlorination theory including breakpoint chlorination, de-chlorination
chemistry, chlorination and de-chlorination equipment, and onsite generation of sodium hypochlorite. On
microbiology, Fecal Coliform Bacteria, Activated sludge microbiology including filament identification and
troubleshooting, UV Absorbance and Transmittance (UVA & UVT), University of Limpopotraviolet (UV) disinfection systems “UV
disinfection theory and UV system O&M”. Further, cases of outbreaks that have happened in the past,
where infection was due to the transmission by waterborne pathogen will be used. Analytic methods used
to trace disease pathogens to the water sources will be studied to establish whether these methods were
the best to be applied in each case or better ones coUniversity of Limpopod have been used instead. In addition the modUniversity of Limpopoe will
deal with practically detecting possible pathogens in water and assessing whether or not this is corroborated
with clinical data of disease outbreak from neighboring clinics or hospitals. Students will learn how to make
sense of data resUniversity of Limpopoting from lab analysis. Training on advocacy on ways to avoid water transmitted diseases
in communities will also be covered (community activism). APPLIED COMPONENT: The applied
component is an assignment to gather data on the in- and output of a dysfunctional water treatment process
(potable and sewage) and come up with adequate interventions for quality improvement to meet the output
standards (laboratory situation)

Description:
The module comprehensively illustrates the diversity of animal life at vertebrate level (Pisces, Amphibia, Reptilia,
Aves and Mammalia). Relationships among groups, basic body plans and adaptations to make the most of and be
successful in their respective environments are examined. The module is based on review, morpho-functional and
adaptation studies of vertebrates. Additionally, specific examples of poisonous and venomous animals in each group
will be highlighted as well as their poisonous or venomous structures, effects and possible treatment.

Lectures Practicals Tutorials Seminars
4 2 0 0

● Explain the relationship between the different vertebrate groups.
● Know the major divisions of the vertebrates.
● Understand the criteria of evolutionary relationships.
● Distinguish between the characteristics of the different vertebrate phyla.
● Describe anatomical differences among the different vertebrate groups.
● Illustrate competence to classify vertebrate specimens based on
characteristic features.
Assessment Criteria

illustrated by different vertebrate species.
● Illustrate knowledge related to aspects of feeding, locomotion, osmo-
regulation, etc. of selected representatives of vertebrates.
● Describe the venom/poison apparatus of a variety of organisms.
● Illustrate competence related to the knowledge of the clinical symptoms
of humans in reaction to envenomation.
● Know the treatment of envenomation.

Description:
Part of this course deals with the fundamental principles of evolution and evolutionary analysis. The accent in this
part is on an introduction to basic evolutionary concepts, mechanisms of evolutionary change, Mendelian genetics
in populations, evolution at multiple loci, adaptation, and mechanisms of speciation. The second part of this course
deals with aspects of conservation genetics, particularly evolutionary genetics of natural populations, effects of
population size reduction and applications from theory to practice. The last part of the course includes introductory
aspects to biodiversity.
Schedule Sessions per week
Lectures Practicals Tutorials Seminars
4 2 0 0
Assessment
● Define the various concepts in the module
● Explain evolution.
● Explain natural selection and evaluate its effect on evolution.
● Explain the theory of evolution by natural selection.
● Show how phylogenies and phylogenetic trees are applied to illustrate
evolution.
● Describe Darwinian fitness.
● Differentiate between adaptation and pre-adaptation.
● Explain mutation and evaluate its effect on evolution.
● Explain heritability and evaluate its effect on evolution.
● Explain and illustrate where new alleles come from.
● Explain and illustrate where new genes come from.
● Explain and illustrate chromosome alterations.
● Measure and calculate genetic variation in natural populations.
Assessment Criteria ● Interpret the effect of different levels of genetic variation in natural
populations.
● Explain the Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium Principle with all its
assumptions.
● Explain and analyse the effects of selection, mutation, migration, genetic
drift and non-random mating on Mendelian population genetics.
● Calculate frequencies using the Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium Principle
and interpret the meaning of the results.
● Determine the extent to which a trait is heritable.
● Determine the strength of selection on a trait.
● Predict the evolutionary response to selection.
● Differentiate among modes of selection and the resultant maintenance of
genetic variation.
● Explain and calculate genetic diversity using different measures.
● Indicate how molecular genetics are applied in conservation biology.
Name: Conservation Genetics

Description:
The content of this modUniversity of Limpopoe consists of a knowledge and application component.
The knowledge component will cover the following: physical test of drinking water including sampling,
equipment’s, procedures, analysis, interpretation of resUniversity of Limpopots and report writing (turbidity, turbidity standards,
color, odour, threshold-odour test, and taste). It will also look into chemical tests of water including sampling,
equipment’s, procedures, analysis, interpretation of resUniversity of Limpopots and report writing on hardness, magnesium,
alkalinity, phenolphthalein alkalinity, sodium hydroxide, sodium carbonate, calcium, magnesium carbonate
and calcium hydroxide, carbon dioxide, pH value, calcium carbonate stability test, jar testing, softening
reaction test, residual chlorine, conventional orthotolidine test, chlorine demand, iron and fluorides. The
modUniversity of Limpopoe will end up by bacteriological examination of water including sampling, equipment’s, procedures,
analysis, interpretation of resUniversity of Limpopots and report writing (standard plate count, standard test for bacteria of the
coliform group, membrane-filter techniques for determining number of coliform microbes”, microscopic
examination of water “grouping of micro-organisms into bacteria and protozoa), and enumeration of micro-
organisms”. The applied component is an assignment to report the water treatment process (potable and
sewage) in all its steps by gathering of process data (laboratory situation)

environment.

The module traces the development of Public Administration as a discipline and reflects on its Nature of
meaning. Various stages or phases of the development of Public Administration are presented as well as the
origins and development of Public Administration as a scientific discipline; nature of the discipline; concepts of

principles and the environment of Public Admiration; the scientific nature of the discipline. Concepts which
form the main content of the discipline of public administration’s theoretical basis form part as well as the
distinction of various schools and approaches, principles and environment of Public Administration.

Description:
In business ethics, we consider business actions and decisions in the light of moral principles
and values, and ask whether ethical motives in business activity would make business better
and more successful; ethical values already implied in business and market activity, assess
how business does and should affect our individual and social lives, and ask what role
business and its values (could) play in our society as a whole; examine issues and conflicts
that typically arise in business that have moral aspects to them, such as the way employers
Module Content:
treat their employees, employees their employers, and the ways businesses treat their
competitors, their customers, their society, and even their environment; the practical
question of whether a (morally) good life can be lived by those who wholehearted devote
themselves to business success. These matters all centre on questions about human action
and the good life.
Students taking this course will learn to
• identify the moral questions that business activity specifically creates
• distinguish between ethical and other types of values
• recognize ethical considerations and values relevant to business activity
• evaluate common beliefs about ethics—especially common beliefs about the role
of ethics in business
• reflect on the nature of business, realize alternatives models for conducting
business
Name: Business Ethics and Valued IIA

Description:
Managers need relevant information that is useful for planning, controlling and decision-
making. This course is to illustrate how relevant information is developed for decision-making
in the changing environment, as well as to demonstrate how information is analysed and
reported to facilitate decision making. This subject area aims to provide tools that support
analytical reasoning that contributes to effective management and decision making in the
Module Content: context of real world scenarios. The content of this course has been carefully selected from
various disciplines including microeconomics, operations research, production and inventory
management, corporate finance, organizational behaviour, corporate strategy, management
accounting proper (costing) and systems design and analysis. The module draws on a broad
understanding and application of economic principles and business quantitative methods to
resolution of strategic and operational management problems.
131After successfully completing the module students should be able to:
• Design, implement and manage the quality control system in the firm
• Identify and respond to reportable irregularities
• Establish and evaluate overall financial goals
• Analys the value of a business
• Plan and monitor an entity’s financing
• evaluate investment decisions and recommend, based on detailed assessment
financing strategies to implement investment decisions
• evaluate and manage risk impacting on value creation by a business
• Managef financial risks as part of the entity’s risk management policy
• Develop or analyse business plans and financial proposals
